stance_1: I am aware of environmental impacts of meat
stance_2: I was raised to believe animals are for consumption
justification: Being aware of the environmental impacts of meat conflicts with being raised to believe animals are for consumption, as the former introduces potential concerns about the practice.

stance_1: I do not enjoy the taste of meat
stance_2: I eat meat for health reasons
justification: The interviewee explicitly states they do not enjoy the taste of meat but eat it for health reasons, showing a conflict between enjoyment and motivation.

stance_1: I do not enjoy the taste of meat
stance_2: I eat meat to get protein
justification: The interviewee states they eat meat for protein despite not enjoying the taste, indicating a conflict between taste preference and nutritional motivation.

stance_1: I do not enjoy the taste of meat
stance_2: I eat meat when it is available on campus
justification: The interviewee chooses to eat meat on campus when available, even though they do not enjoy the taste, indicating a behavior that conflicts with preference.

stance_1: I eat meat for health reasons
stance_2: I eat meat to get protein
justification: The interviewee explicitly connects eating meat for health to its protein content, showing strong support between these stances.

stance_1: I eat meat for health reasons
justification: The interviewee mentions iron as a possible health benefit of meat, supporting the health motivation.

stance_1: I eat meat for health reasons
stance_2: I was raised to believe animals are for consumption
justification: The upbringing that animals are for consumption implicitly supports the idea that eating meat is normal and healthy.

stance_1: I eat meat to get protein
justification: Both protein and iron are mentioned as reasons for considering meat healthy, supporting each other as nutritional motivations.

stance_1: I eat meat when it is available on campus
stance_2: I eat meat for health reasons
justification: The interviewee chooses meat on campus due to the belief that it is good for them, linking availability and health motivation.

stance_1: I eat meat when it is available on campus
stance_2: I eat meat to get protein
justification: Choosing meat when available is supported by the desire to get protein, as explicitly stated.

stance_1: I eat meat when it is available on campus
stance_2: I was raised to believe animals are for consumption
justification: Upbringing to see animals as food supports the tendency to eat meat when available.

stance_1: I was raised to believe animals are for consumption
stance_2: My family are big meat eaters
justification: The interviewee explicitly states that their family culture and upbringing reinforce the belief that animals are for consumption.
